questiontext.text:
(a) Complete the truth table below for {@operator[1]@}.


\(A\) \(B\) \(A {@operator[2]@} B\)
true true [[input:ans1]]
true false [[input:ans2]]
false true [[input:ans3]]
false false [[input:ans4]]

[[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans2]] [[validation:ans3]] [[validation:ans4]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

(b) On a day where it is raining, I claim that "today {@statement_A[1]@} {@operator[3]@} {@statement_B[1]@}".
Which of the following options describes the truth of this statement.

[[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

[[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution:

(a) The correct truth table for the implication operator is the following,

\(A\) \(B\) \(A {@operator[2]@} B\)
true true {@t_ans1@}
true false {@t_ans2@}
false true {@t_ans3@}
false false {@t_ans4@}

(b) To evaluate the given statement, we can separate the two claims as,

\(A\): "{@statement_A[1]@}"
\(B\): "{@statement_B[1]@}"

We can now use the truth table in part (a) to evaluate the full statement.


We know immediately from the information in the question that statement \(A\) is {@if statement_A[2]=1 then "true" else "false"@}, so we have a case of either the {@if statement_A[2]=1 then "first or second" else "third or fourth"@} row in the table.

\(A\) \(B\) \(A {@operator[2]@} B\)
{@if statement_A[2]=1 then "true" else "false"@} true {@worked_sol_opt1: if statement_A[2]=1 then t_ans1 else t_ans3@}
{@if statement_A[2]=1 then "true" else "false"@} false {@worked_sol_opt2: if statement_A[2]=1 then t_ans2 else t_ans4@}

{@ if worked_sol_opt1=worked_sol_opt2 then sconcat("Then, from the table we see that as long as there is not a contradiction, the statement must be ", worked_sol_opt1, ".
Supposing there is no contradiction and the statement is then ", worked_sol_opt1, ", I am therefore ", if worked_sol_opt1="true" then "telling the truth" else "not telling the truth", ", so the claim \\(B\\) is ", worked_sol_evB_1: if (worked_sol_opt1="true" and statement_B[2]=1) or (worked_sol_opt1="false" and statement_B[2]=2) then "true" else "false", ".
This corresponds to the ", if worked_sol_evB_1="true" then "first" else "second", " row in the shortened table above.
Hence, this case is permissible (there is no contradiction), and the statement is ", worked_sol_opt1, ".") else sconcat("Then, from the table we see that the as long as there is not a contradiction, the statement could be either true or false.

", "

Let us suppose first that the statement is true, so we are in the ", if worked_sol_opt1="true" then "first" else "second", " row of the shortened truth table above. Since I am therefore telling the truth, we know statement \\(B\\) is ", worked_sol_evB_2: if statement_B[2]=1 then "true" else "false", ".
Now looking at the relevant row in the shortened truth table, this ", if worked_sol_opt1=worked_sol_evB_2 then "correctly corresponds to the evaluation of \\(B\\), so this case is permissible and the statement could be true." else "does not correspond to the evaluation of \\(B\\), so we have a contradiction and the statement cannot be true.", "

", "

Let us suppose now that the statement is false, so we are in the ", if worked_sol_opt1="false" then "first" else "second", " row of the shortened truth table above. Since I am therefore not telling the truth, we know statement \\(B\\) is ", worked_sol_evB_3: if statement_B[2]=2 then "true" else "false", ".
Now looking at the relevant row in the shortened truth table, this ", if worked_sol_opt2=worked_sol_evB_3 then "correctly corresponds to the evaluation of \\(B\\), so this case is permissible and the statement could be false." else "does not correspond to the evaluation of \\(B\\), so we have a contradiction and the statement cannot be false.", "

", "

Then, considering both cases, ", if t_ans5=1 then "the statement is true." else if t_ans5=2 then "the statement is false." else if t_ans5=3 then "the statement is neither true nor false since each option gives a contradiction." else if t_ans5=4 then "the statement could be either true or false.") @}

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text:
You have not given the correct truth table for {@operator[1]@}.
The truth table you have given is actually the truth table for {@node3_feedback@}.

falsefeedback.text:
The first row of your truth table is incorrect.
If \(A\) is true and \(B\) is true, then "\(A\) {@operator[3]@} \(B\)" is {@t_ans1@}.

The second row of your truth table is incorrect.
If \(A\) is true and \(B\) is false, then "\(A\) {@operator[3]@} \(B\)" is {@t_ans2@}.

The third row of your truth table is incorrect.
If \(A\) is false and \(B\) is true, then "\(A\) {@operator[3]@} \(B\)" is {@t_ans3@}.

The fourth row of your truth table is incorrect.
If \(A\) is false and \(B\) is false, then "\(A\) {@operator[3]@} \(B\)" is {@t_ans4@}.

truefeedback.text:
The statement given cannot be true because this will lead to a contradiction.
Writing the two claims in the statement as \(A\) and \(B\), for "{@statement_A[1]@}" and "{@statement_B[1]@}" respectively, we can use the truth table in part (a) to evaluate the whole statement.

From the information in the question, we have that statement \(A\) is {@if statement_A[2]=1 then "true" else "false"@}.
We also have that if the overall statement is true, then I am telling the truth and statement \(B\) is {@if statement_B[2]=1 then "true" else "false"@}.

These two observations cannot be simultaneously true in any of the rows in the truth table for {@operator[1]@}.
So, the statement "\(A\) {@operator[3]@} \(B\) " cannot be true.

You are correct that the statement given can be true.
However, it can also be false, so the correct answer is that the statement could be either true or false.
